{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3485264,"name":"Gabe Huberman","username":"ghubie42","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/d9b06d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T01:51:16.603Z","cooked":"

In the past, my team has used a drill with a XT60 connector wired to it (I attached an image below) so that we could use CIMs/775s for prototyping without having to wire them to motor controllers or the PDH. This has worked well for us but as we have fully phased out of using those motors we are looking for a way to do the same for a Falcon. The main issue is figuring out how to trick the Talon to think it is connected to the CANbus.

It would be great if there is a way to control the speed but it is not important.

Screenshot 2025-01-16 at 6.50.04 PM1188×1578 217 KB

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-01-17T02:02:42.263Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":179,"reads":184,"readers_count":183,"score":936.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":482218,"topic_slug":"mobile-way-to-run-a-falcon-500-motor","display_username":"Gabe Huberman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71431,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/mobile-way-to-run-a-falcon-500-motor/482218/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3485280,"name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","username":"Billfred","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T02:12:07.281Z","cooked":"

Why put it on CAN? If you’re just prototyping at medium fidelity, I’d connect it to something that generates a PWM signal and run it that way. Something like the AndyMark Thrifty Throttle would do the trick.

As for power, I’d find an old PDP/PDB (even the old blue ones would be fine) to get a breaker in the mix on principle. Or get fancy and use a smaller automotive one.

Like the Thrifty Nova runner board but for any motor?

The Thrifty Bot

PRE-ORDER: Thrifty Motor Runner Board

The Thrifty Motor Runner Board is designed to work with the Thrifty Nova to provide a no-code interface to running a brushless motor. It works over a cable which stops the motor when unplugged. The Thrifty Motor Runner comes with a printed case and a...

Price: USD 19.99

ghubie42:

This has worked well for us but as we have fully phased out of using those motors

out of curiosity, why didn’t you all keep these for prototyping only? Is there a reason they did not work well for prototyping?

We just slowly started integrating Falcons and Neos into our prototypes so that we could have more accurate data for prototypes that would be close to the final robot performance we expect.

It’s debatably mobile but we run falcons for prototyping by just pumping 12v into them and control speed with a cheap servo tester. We get our juice from an old pdp but you could probably rig one up to a hand drill and hot glue the servo tester on top.

I had that exact same need… Ive got a build thread on here for a joystick controller that runs a Kraken happily using PWM. With the MAJOR advantage of let go=stop

FRC Driver Station App for Android Technical
It takes some work to make a motor runner this fancy, but the end result can make a lead screw dance on a Kraken! The brain is a normal PWM servo tester; I’ve desoldered the pot and wired it to a joystick to get that awesome “let go and it stops” action. A big anderson and some bits give you a nice clean “run that Kraken” solution. [image]
